question: Question_07
sols:
Using the \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ratio_test}{ratio test}
seems appropriate here. If we denote the general term of the series by

\begin{align*}a_k = \frac{k(k+1)}{2^k} \quad\text{for all } k \geq 1\end{align*} Then the
ratio test asks us to look at

\begin{align*}
\frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} &= \frac{(k+1)(k+2)2^k}{k(k+1)2^{k+1}}\\
&= \frac{k+2}{2k}\end{align*} (Note: we removed the absolute value since the terms are
clearly all positive). And so

\begin{align*}\lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} = \lim_{k \to \infty}\frac{k+2}{2k} = \frac{1}{2}\end{align*}
Since this is a number less than one, the ratio test guarantees that the
series converges absolutely.
